variant.sectionHeader: UNIVERSALITY AND INDIVIDUALITY: THE INTERACTION OF NOUN PHRASE DETERMINERS IN COPULA'? CLAUSES
variant.author: Jobn C. Mal!cry
variant.affiliation: Political Science Department and Artificial Intelligence l.aboratory Massachusetts Institute of Technology
variant.bodyText: This paper presents in implemented theory for quantifying noun phrases in clauses containing copular verbs (e.g.. 'be' and 'become'). Proceeding from recent theoretical work by Jackendolf WWI, this computational theory recognizes the dependence ()I' the quantification decision on the definiteness. indefiniteness, or clir;sness ()I' both the subject and object of copular verbs in English. Jackendoffs intuition about the quantilicational interdependence of subject and object has been imported In tin his broader cognitive theory and reformulated within a constraint propagation framework, Extensions reported here include. the addition of more active deter miners. the expansion of determiner categories, and the treatment or displaced objects. A further finding is tht:t quantilicational constraints may propagate across some clausal boundaries. The algorithm is used by the RELATUS Natural Language Understanding System during a phase of analysis that posts constraints to produce a 'constraint tree.' This phase comes after creation of syntactic deep structure and before sentential reference in a semantic-network model. Incorporation of the quantification algorithm in a larger system that parses sentences and builds semantic models from them makes RELATUS able to acquire taxonotnic and identity in formation from text.

-1 lie quantification of noun phrases, determining their universality or individuality, is critical for the automatic acquisition of taxonomic and identity information from natural language sentences. Automatic acquisition can convert ordinary texts into sources of taxonomic and identity information for use by learning and reasoning programs in artificial intelligence. Such information can also find use in efforts to develop selection restrictions from lexical sources. Of course, proper quantification of noun phrases also plays a key role in computer programs that endeavor to understand natural language. 'the theory for computing the quantilicational status of noun phrases for the case ()I copular verbs (e.g.. 'be' and 'become') was inspired by recent theoretical work of Jackendoff fackendolf noted that quantification of noun phrases or copular ,,erhs depends jointly on the detei miners of both the subject NI) and the object. NI' [1083, 00-0 I, 061.1 Ifs intuition has been rel'ormulated, augmented, and implemented in the

.rhe implemented quantification theory is used by RELATUS as it incrementally builds a semantic model. This method recovers class and identity inliffmation from ordinary English sentences. Although the semantic model must be occasionally queried to resolve quantilicational ambiguities, time int.thod is primarily syntactic and does not require reasoning. -the computational simplicity and broad co■erage of the theory allow successful quantification of noun phrases in most copular clauses. Wolk is in progress to extend the analysis to partitives and thereby yield a comprehensie analysis. While this approach does not treat ‘tich difficult issues such as belief contexts and metaphorical usages, it. does address most literal cases. Since the quantification I. I will usc "object NP" to refer to what is frequently called a "predicate object." 2. The experimental RELAI US Natural Language Understanding System represents the corubined efforts of Gavan Duffy and the author. Gavan Duffy is responsible for the parser, the categorial disambiguator [Duffy, 19854 the lexicon and lexicon utilities. The author is responsible for the representation system, the reference system, the component that maps deep structure to semantics, the quantification system, the inversion system, and the question-answering component

theory is deployed in a natural language system that parses sentences and builds a :iemantic model from them. RELATUS becomes, among other things, a system for acquiring class structure information from ordinary English texts.

variant.subsectionHeader: Syntactic Analysis Input: Text Stream Output: Surface Structure I /cep Structure Sentential Constraint Posting Input: Surface Structure I )eep Structure Output: Sentential Constraint Tree Sentential Reference
variant.listItem: • The quantification algorithm is embedded in a sentential consti.aint-posting process [Duffy and Mal!cry, 19841 shown in figure 1. Sentential constraint-posting creates a constraint tree that corresponds to roughly what
variant.bodyText: uanshondlional .,:iiinuniirians call /ogica/ fOrnt. The constraint tree is used to perform intersentential teferencc (merging successive sentences into a single semantic-network model) [Mafiery, 19)01. "l 'he input to constraint-posting phase is both surlace structure and deep structure canonicalited hy a transformational parser Puffy, 191S5a). In a depth-first, bottom up walk of the deep structure, constraints describing grammatical rclations are posted on non-terminal parse-graph nodes.3 When verbs in minor clauses (i.e.. clauses other than relative clatises or clausal adjuncts) are reached, they supervise the quantification of noun phrases they command. H. these verbs are copular verbs, the copular interconstraint algorithm is applied. In other cases, another experimental algorithm perliums quantification by drawing on logical relations l'rom surface structure. The result of this process is the sentential constraint tree. It is a hierarchical description of grammatical and logical relations that is suitable input for the reference system. By sequentially referencing the sentences of a text, a semantic model of the text is incrementally constructed.

Within a constraint-posting framework, the basic task of NP quantification is to decide whether to post a constraint marking the NP as an individual or a universal. Since the task involves knowing the specific subject and object of a copular verb, it is delegated to a higher constituent, the verb. I his delegation is motivated by the principle of local decision-molting which holds that decisions should be located where all required inhumation is both available and proximate. In this case, only the verb knows the identities (if both thmn phrases due to the hietarchical structure ()t erammatical ielations. •Ihus, when a verb posts its own tat:rent MI constraints, it also directs the quantification of NI's that it dominates (e.g., its subject and o)ject). This procedure was reformulated in a constraint propagation [Waltz, 19751 franiev.oik because features of a single constituent cannot be determined independently of other constituents in the sentential &Ovation. Since qtiantilicational constraint propagates in both directions, this process is a type of CrillAlinielit kuttmately, the possible states of NPs are only three: definite. indefinite. and class. Because the number of possible Ni' states is small (3) and the numher of variables is also small (2), a simple table-lookup tilgtiothm 'compiles stibject and object quallii fications For all possible configurations of NP deliniteness.5
variant.listItem: 3. At present. the RFLATUS system builds sentential constraints using the canonical grammatical relations of the sentence, the quantification status of noun phrases, and the truth values of verbs. Work is in progress to incorporate temporal constraints on verbs. temporal adjectives, and various types of context markers. 4. The RELATUS parser uses non-standard parse graphs. A 'kern' corresponds to a clause while a 'verbal' is something like a verb phrase except that the kern tells it what its subject, object, and modifiers are at constraint-posting time. For further details. see Dully [19854

variant.bodyText: The actual task of determining the quantificational status of the NI's decomposes into three steps.
variant.listItem: (1) The definiteness of the noun phrases is ascertained by examining the determiners and several other parameters. The algorithm is
variant.bodyText: summarized by figure 2. Another algorithm described by figure 3 is used for determinerless plural NPs. (2) The quantificational status of the subject and object is determined by looking each case up in the table depicted by Figure 4. Potentially ambiguous cases (marked with an asterisk) may. require relbrencing the noun phrase in the semantic model to resolve the ambiguity. Example sentences for the eases in figure 4 are found in figure 5. (3) The verb-phrase node informs each NP of its quantification (the results of step 2). and they in 5. The conversion of constraint propagation into a table lookup approach is possible in this special case because there are only two variables, the subject and the object. In the general case, the size of the table is exponential in the number of variables. turn post corresponding constraints on themselves.
variant.table: Fig. 3. Categories for Determiner-less NPs Characteristic of NP NP Classification Singular Proper Noun Definite Plural Indefinite Possessively Modified Definite Animate Pronouns Definite
variant.bodyText: In his discussion, Jackendolf [1983: 77-106, esp. 88-91. 94-1061 only categorizes determiners according to the distinction between definite and indefinite . I have added classness to his scheme in order to cope with such determiners as 'any' and 'every'. While lackendoffs examples use only the determiners 'a', 'an', and 'the', I have found interpretations lig additional determiners which are summarized in figure 2. Jackendoll considers proper nouns to be definite and the same is done here, except in certain cases of plural proper nouns which are interpreted as the plural indefinite (see S2I in fiettre 5). The taldition of the class categorization calls for the class determiners in the bottom of figure 2. The determiner, 'no', is treated as the negation of 'all.' Thus, the NP is quantified as a class and the copula negated. While SIO and S18 in figure 5 are valid, S19 is not. There are restrictions on where 'no* can appear. It cannot modify both the subject ond object. Nor can it modify the object when the subject is indefinite (S19) or a universal (520), but it can when the subject is definite (S18). These restrictions seem generally valid Or literal cases even though some idiomatic and metaphorical constructions may vii date them. Various cases of determiner-less NPs are handled by the algorithm that determines NP definiteness. Those cases are listed in Figure 3. The indefinite category may be incompletely handled because the theory does not yet encompass partitives -- indefinite NI's that partition collections of individuals or universals. 11111S, determiner-less NI's with plural head nouns are not analyzed for partitive readings.
variant.table: Case Sentence Determiner Classification Noun Phrase Quantification Subject Object Subject Object Cl Sl, S2 Indefinite Indefinite Class Class C2 S3 Indefinite Class Class Class C3 S4 Indefinite Definite Class Class C4 S5, S6, S7 Definite Definite Individuals Individual* C5 S8. S9 Definite Indefinite Individual* Class C6 Sll Definite Class Individual Class+ C7 S12 Class Definite Class Class C8 S13 Class Class Class Class+ C9 S10, S14 Class Indefinite Class Class Indicates the possibility of quantificational ambiguity. + Indicates Mai grammatical sentences must have displaced objects.
variant.bodyText: Partitive determiners may engender two readings. I he NPs they modify can he read as either colle;:tions of individuals or universals. Sonic partitive determiners such as 'some,' 'each,' 'most', 'few', or 'many' are used to make statements about subsets of a collection. With the exception of 'some,' these are missing from figure 2 pending research about how to determine their quantification. 'Some is interpreted just as an indefinite because of its high frequency. .1 he determiners 'all,' 'any,' and 'every,' were included because they refer to the entirety of a collection. None of the partitive determiners, even the ones currently used to determine classness. vill he adequately handled until completion of continuing work on the syntactic parse graphs and the interaction characteristics of partitives. Sometimes copular verbs take adjectives in the object position, leaving no apparent object. Some of these adjectives have a displaced object as in S2, S11, Si). Sb and S16 in figure S. Were there actually no object, the quantilication of the subject would he determined in isoiution (using a dilThrent algorithm). When the adjective has an object. that object is used to perform the NP interconstraint with the subject. Cases C6 and C3 are impossible (S22 and S24) unless the sentences have displaced objects (S11 and S1)). I lowever, this is not the case. for Co where a copular verb is modal and has a partitive determiner on its object. This suggests that partitive readings of class determiners may make these cases acceptable and that displaced objects simply make such a reading easier. nbplaced .mbjeds appear as the NPs vvhich 'relative pronouns- bind ill relative clauses or appositives. 515 provides an example id interconstraint across a relative clause. There, 'a philosopher' is the displaced subject of the displaced object, 'an Ionian stoic.' Interestingly, 'a philosopher' is also a displaced object with respect to Alary.' Recall that constraint posting proceeds from the bottom of the pause graph up the hierarchy of grammatical relations with quantilication following along and being governed by major verbs. In SI5, quantification interconstrami is first applied to 'a philosopher' and 'an Ionian stoic' by the copula of the relative clause. [hen, it is applied to 'Mary' and 'a philosopher' hy the major copula. Since the liist NP interconstraint fixes 'a philosopher' as a universal, that result is then carried over into the imerconstraint with 'Mary.. In both S15 and S16, die quantificational constrain', proparates across clausal boundaries because both clause share the same NP as an object and a subject. Cases such as these should not lead to inconsistent quantifications. Instead, they should agree. attesting to the soundness of the algorithm. Jackendolf [1983: 971 argues that cases C4 and C5 in figure 4 are semantically ambiguous. This ambiguity seems only to hold for the determiner 'the' and is resolved by a simple relerence of the NP in the semantic rcpresentation.6 if the ambiguous NP has no referent in the current discourse focus [Gross, 1971, then the NP must be a universal. If there is a referent, it is either a universal or an individual, and the same

variant.bodyText: quantification should be chosen. Where both appear relation, identity between them is represented. rdentity in the discourse focus, the individual reading is preferred. between two universals is represented with two generic This is particularly important for C4 because the status of classifications indicating that each universal is a subset of the subject is needed to predict that of object. In either the other. For predicate adjectives, a special token (e.g., case, both must have the same quantilicational status. 'HQ,' HAS-QUALITY') is used as the !elation and the adjective as the object in order to represent a one-place property [Winston 1980, 19821. This avoids confusion when a word token has uses both as an adjective and a noun. Because RH .ATUS incorporates a theory of ituerprelive semantics, where syntactic canonicalization is performed on input and semantic equivalence is determined (ally through reasoning over a syntactically canonical rcpresentation, this encoding system is particularly appropriate. Because no post-processing is needed Lou substitute distinct tokens lin- the different types of linking relations, this encoding also simplifies quantification ()I' copular clauses, and Mei-chive, the constraint posting process in general. The encoding method only iequires a small constant inueasc in tune br walking the created class structure, thus, the potential gam in efficiency by using a Imre. ;:xplicit encoding technique is marginal. :Ind mit,,ht he olket by other factors. 'File analysis of NP quantification in copular clauses is significantly simplified by the fact that there is no need to analyze quantifier scoping. 'Ibis follows from the absence of a passive interpretation for copular verbs. lbey are specialized in conveying classilicational intOrmation rather than expressing active changes of state. Since there is no agent and no object which is acted upon, passive constructions can have no meaningful interpretation. Interchanging the subject and the object either has no effect on identity statements or inverts the
variant.table: classification ielat;onship in other cases. Thus, the semantic specialiiation of copular verhs in conveying links ()I class hierarchies simplifies aspects ()I' their sy ntactic analysis. Fig. 6. Classification of Copular Links in REIATUS Subject Real Object Link Classification Individual Universal Ordinary Classification Conclusions Universal Universal Gencric Classification The copula' interconstrinnt algorithm presented In Individual Identity Relation • in this paper has been surprisingly robust in large text Either Adjective Quality applications Over the past yem. Once the research on
variant.bodyText: partitives is completed. the :dim will cover an even larger proportion of copular verh cases. Work has been done on copular questions hut is Lou) complex for discussion 'here, largely clue to pragmatic interactions. Conjunctions have been treated just like ordinary. N Ps, except that error checking en ailes that ill Nps in conjunctions agree in definiteness. rhe idea of constraint propagation has been extended experimentally to ntin-eopular verbs using a different propagation algorithm. 'lite approach has been successful thus far. However, mole research is required to analyze interciions between carious quantification .ilgorithins .ind to asceitain Thu propagation characteristics of different verbs, according to their senses and meanings. Quantifier sowing, algorithm interaction. and differential propagation are some of characteristics of general constituent interconstraint that make it more difficult. In general. propagation of quantificational constraints, seems a promising approach to previously recalcitrant imoblems. Even so, strong psychological claims must await further research and exhaustive analyses across languages. A Climpse At Semantics Since RFTXFUS incrementally constructs a semantic model of the sentences it analyzes, the copular interconstraint algorithm allows a class structure to be automatically acquired. 'I he way in which this intOrmation is represented in RELATUS exploits the encoding scheme underlying f-:nglish usage of wpular %.erhs. fhis encoding method allows limr types of linking relations to he encoded using a single token. (i.e., 'be.). Ibis encoding is swum:toted in figure 6. Since the types can he differentiated according to the quantification of the nodes linked. the unique representation of each link type does not require the introduction of ad hoc tokens. Ordinary and generic classification are used to construct die taxonomy. When two individuals are linked by a 'be' 6. Such a strategy has been followed for other types of 40 ambiguous preposition and clause bindings [Hirst. 1981, 1984; Duffy, 19854 Recent interest in developing lexicons to support computer understanding of natural language [Walker and Amster, 19851 suggests the need for effective methods of augmenting our lexicographical knowledge using large corpora and unrestricted text. Selection restrictions are an important type of information to accumulate because they are needed not only to distinguish different senses of words but also to recognize metaphorical uses. Since accumulation of selection restrictions requires it, acquisition of taxonomic inlbrmation is a priority. The copular interconstraint algorithm introduced in this paper provides a basis fbr acquiring large taxonomies from unrestricted texts. A lifter can he used to quickly prune all non-copular sentences zis well as difficult copular sentences involving helief, and perhaps, time contexts. The remaining sentences can be parsed, quantified and represented in a large semantic model. This research would not only advance our knowledge of natural taxonomies and selection restrictions hut it would also generate empirical data useful Ibr those studying 'default logics and stereotype hierarchies [Minsky, 1975; Keil, 1979; Reiter, 1980; Brachman, 1982; Etherington and Reiter, 19831. One difficulty with this research program is that an uncertainty principle is at work: The taxonomy used to determine selection restrictions itself depends on recognition of metaphors through selection restrictions. Success in this lexicographical task will require the careful development of effective research strategies.

This paper was improved by comments from Jonathan Connell, Gavan Duffy, Margaret Fleck, Robert Ingria, David McAllester, Rick Lathrop, and David Waltz. This research was encouraged and supported in various ways by Hayward Alker, Mike Brady, Berthold Horn, Tom Knight, Marvin Minsky, Gerald Sussman, and Patrick Winston, Gavan Dully's parse graphs made this research possible. The RELATUS system was designed and implemented by the author and Gavan Duffy. Tliis research was done at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Support for the Laboratory's artificial intelligence research is provided in part by the Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Department of Defense under Office of Naval Research contract number N00014-80-C-0505. Responsibility for the content, of course, remains with the author.

Jackendoffs intuition about the quantilicational of subject and has been imported In tin his broader cognitive theory and reformulated within a constraint propagation framework, Extensions here the addition more active deter miners. the expansion of determiner categories, and treatment objects. A further finding is tht:t quantilicational constraints may propagate across some clausal boundaries. The algorithm is used by the RELATUS Natural Language Understanding System during a phase of analysis that posts constraints to produce a 'constraint tree.'
